7 Components

To do

7.1 Component

internaluntested

The component Component is the parent class of all components in the UI Kit. It is an abstrac class that it means that it doesn't exist as a CSS class itself but as a mixin that can be inherited in any component.

egeo-c-component

@mixintestedinternal

Injects the general behavior and properties of the abstract class Component to other components of the UI Kit.

Usage

.test {
        @include egeo-c-component;
}

Will product the next result:

.test {
        box-sizing: border-box;
}
Compatibility IE8+, Firefox 29+, Chrome 10+, Edge 12+, Safari 5.1+, Opera 9.5+

7.2 Button

internaluntested

The component Button is officially supported in <a>, <button> and <span> tags. The <input> tag has a particular behavior due to the default values and special implementation dragged from its implementation in the oldest browsers.

<input> tag can be perfectly used but keep in mind that the input type doesn't allow to use an icon inside the text (that is place in the value attribute).

egeo-c-button-modifier

@mixinuntestedinternal

Creates a new modifier which is a type of button with the properties passed as parameters. Sass True doesn't work well with mixins that generates completely new classes outside the one marked as input.

Usage

.test {
       @include egeo-c-button-modifier('warning',
                                   (background: orange, margin:0, color: white), // Sass map that includes the styles to be placed in the modifier
                                   (background: black, margin:0, color: white), // Sass map that includes the styles to be placed in the modifier on hover
                                   (background: blue, margin:0, color: white)  // Sass map that includes the styles to be placed in the modifier on focus
                                   );
}

Will product the next result:

.test--warning {
        background: orange;
     color: white;
     margin: 0;
}

.test--warning:hover {
     background: black;
     color: white;
     margin: 0;
}

.test--warning:focus {
     background: blue;
     color: white;
     margin: 0;
}

egeo-c-button

@mixinuntestedinternal

Internally used to create the Egeo buttons in an extensible way. Sass True doesn't work well with mixins that generates completely new classes outside the one marked as input.

Compatibility IE6+, Firefox 29+, Chrome 10+, Edge 12+, Safari 5.1+, Opera 9.5+

How to extend the button

   .#{$egeo-namespace}c-button {
       @include egeo-c-button;

       // If you want to use the modifier constructor
       @include egeo-c-button-modifier('name-of-you-modifier',
                                   (background: #000, margin:0), // Sass map that includes the styles to be placed in the modifier
                                   (background: #777, margin:0), // Sass map that includes the styles to be placed in the modifier on hover
                                   (background: #fff, margin:0)  // Sass map that includes the styles to be placed in the modifier on focus
                                   );

       // your code here
   }

How to create a new button inheriting from button

   .my-button {
       @include egeo-c-button;

       // If you want to use the modifier constructor
       @include egeo-c-button-modifier('name-of-you-modifier',
                                   (background: #000, margin:0), // Sass map that includes the styles to be placed in the modifier
                                   (background: #777, margin:0), // Sass map that includes the styles to be placed in the modifier on hover
                                   (background: #fff, margin:0)  // Sass map that includes the styles to be placed in the modifier on focus
                                   );

       // your code here
   }

This script will create a class called my-button with the shared styles of all egeo-buttons, other class called my-button---name-of-your-modifier with the default values of the first Sass map, a pseudo-class called my-button---name-of-your-modifier:hover with the values of the second Sass map and a last pseudo-class called my-button---name-of-your-modifier:focus with the values of the third Sass map.

How to create a disabled state

Automatically, if exist a button which name is disabled, then the system will also create a pseudo-class called :disabled that will work when buttons will be tagged with the HTML5 attribute disabled.

   .my-button {
       @include egeo-c-button;

       // If you want to use the modifier constructor
       @include egeo-c-button-modifier('disabled',
                                   (background: #777, margin:0), // Sass map that includes the styles to be placed in the modifier
                                   (background: #777, margin:0), // Sass map that includes the styles to be placed in the modifier on hover
                                   (background: #777, margin:0)  // Sass map that includes the styles to be placed in the modifier on focus
                                   );

       // your code here
   }
Compatibility untested

How the buttons Sass maps work

There are two different Sass Maps we can work with to create new buttons or remove those that were created as default ones. The map $egeo-c-buttons is used to describe the default buttons defined in the Visual Guidelines. As is defined as !default is perfectly possible to reset it, removing all the buttons pre-configurated.

However, if you want create new buttons and keep the default ones, you can use the second map called $egeo-c-buttons-custom and define there the buttons you need to add.

The system will merge the two maps to renderize the whole buttons defined in both.

We have three inner Sass maps with properties we can modify to create new custom buttons: a map for the default state, other one for the hover state and a last one for the focus state. These Sass maps can include any CSS class. In addition, the general properties the whole buttons share between them will be created in the egeo-c-button class. So, if we want to create a new pair of buttons, we only need to add their definitions to the $egeo-c-buttons-custom map as is shown below:

$egeo-c-buttons: (
    button-1: (
                normal: (background: egeo-get-color(a1), border: 0, color: egeo-get-color(n0)),
                hover: (background: egeo-get-color(a1_dark), border: 0, color: egeo-get-color(n0)),
                focus: (background: egeo-get-color(a1_light), border: 0, color: egeo-get-color(n0))
            ),
    button-2: (
                normal: (background: egeo-get-color(a2), border: 0, color: egeo-get-color(n0)),
                hover: (background: egeo-get-color(a2_dark), border: 0, color: egeo-get-color(n0)),
                focus: (background: egeo-get-color(a2_light), border: 0, color: egeo-get-color(n0))
            )
);

The definition above will generate the next classes:

.egeo-c-button {...}
.egeo-c-button--button-1 {...}
.egeo-c-button--button-1:hover {...}
.egeo-c-button--button-1:focus {...}
.egeo-c-button--button-2 {...}
.egeo-c-button--button-2:hover {...}
.egeo-c-button--button-2:focus {...}

All properties are optional so, if you don't want your button have a background or a border, the only thing you have to do is not including in the map and it will not be renderized.

The default values of the pre-configured buttons defined in the $egeo-c-buttons map are:

<div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><a class="egeo-c-button egeo-c-button--main-1"><i class="egeo-c-icon icon-cog"></i>Main 1</a></div>
<div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><span class="egeo-c-button egeo-c-button--main-2"><i class="egeo-c-icon icon-cog"></i>Main 2</span></div>
<div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><button class="egeo-c-button egeo-c-button--main-3"><i class="egeo-c-icon icon-cog"></i>Main 3</button></div>
<div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><input type="submit" class="egeo-c-button egeo-c-button--secondary-1" value="Secondary 1"></div>
<div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><input type="button" class="egeo-c-button egeo-c-button--small egeo-c-button--secondary-1" value="Secondary 2"></div>
<div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><input type="reset" class="egeo-c-button egeo-c-button--danger" value="Danger action"></div>
<div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><button class="egeo-c-button egeo-c-button--main-3" disabled><i class="egeo-c-icon icon-cog"></i>Disabled button</button></div>
<div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><button class="egeo-c-button egeo-c-button--rounded egeo-c-button--tool-1"><i class="egeo-c-icon icon-cog"></i></button></div>
<div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><button class="egeo-c-button egeo-c-button--rounded egeo-c-button--tool-2"><i class="egeo-c-icon icon-cog"></i></button></div>
<div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><button class="egeo-c-button egeo-c-button--rounded egeo-c-button--tool-ellipsis"><i class="egeo-c-icon icon-waiting"></i></button></div>

Will be renderized to:

Main 1
Main 2

Variables exposed to theming

Variable Default value
$egeo-c-button
true
$egeo-c-button---height
40px
$egeo-c-button---min-width
180px
$egeo-c-button---padding
0 20px
$egeo-c-button---text-align
center
$egeo-c-button---text-transform
uppercase
$egeo-c-button---transition
all .5s
$egeo-c-button--focus---shadow
0 0 5px 0 rgba(egeo-get-color(n8), .5)
$egeo-c-button__c-icon--first-child---margin
0 8px 0 0
$egeo-c-button__c-icon--last-child---margin
0 0 0 8px
$egeo-c-button--small---font-size
egeo-get-font-size(small)
$egeo-c-button--small---height
30px
$egeo-c-button--small---padding
4px 15px
$egeo-c-buttons
Sass map
$egeo-c-buttons-custom
Sass map

The egeo-c-button AngularJS directive

@directiveuntested

Egeo provides an AngularJS directive to create all types of buttons defined with ease. The directive is restricted to HTML Element and called egeo-c-button. Below you can see the properties exposed:

Property Description
type
Submit, Reset or Button
modifier
The name of the button created as a CSS BEM Modifier
label
The label of the button
icon-left
An icon which appears at left side
icon-right
An icon which appears at right side
small
A small version of the button
rounded
A rounded version of the button. A rounded button will hide the label and only show the icon.
at-right
Floats the button to right
popover
internalIt is used to reference popover IDs when the button is linked to a popover.

Usage

Take a look to the samples shown below to see how the properties could be used and combined to get different results:

  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="main-1" data-label="AngularJS Button: Click to test ({{count}})" data-ng-click="count = count + 1"></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="main-2" data-icon-left="icon-cog" data-icon-right="icon-arrow2_down" data-label="AngularJS Button"></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="main-3" data-label="AngularJS Button"></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="secondary-1" data-label="AngularJS Button"></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="secondary-1" data-icon-left="icon-cog" data-small="true" data-label="AngularJS Button Small"></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="danger" data-label="AngularJS Danger Button"></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="danger" data-icon-left="icon-cog" data-label="AngularJS Disabled Button" disabled></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-1" data-rounded="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime"></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-1" data-rounded="true" data-small="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime"></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-2" data-rounded="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime"></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-2" data-rounded="true" data-small="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime"></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-ellipsis" data-rounded="true" data-icon-left="icon-waiting"></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-ellipsis" data-rounded="true" data-small="true" data-icon-left="icon-waiting"></egeo-c-button></div>
  <div style="margin-bottom: 5px; overflow: auto"><egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="ellipsis" data-rounded="true" data-small="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime" data-at-right="true"></egeo-c-button></div>

Dependencies

  • components.component
  • utils.floats - only if you want to float your buttons.

7.3 Icon

tested

The Icon Component is a class to group common styles and behaviors to all icons in an Egeo app.

egeo-c-icon

@mixintestedinternal

Injects the general behavior and properties of the class Icon to other components of the UI Kit.

Note: The Icon component triggers styles in other components if is active.

Usage

.test {
        @include egeo-c-icon;
}

Will product the next result:

.test {
        box-sizing: border-box;
}

Dependencies

  • component
Compatibility IE8+, Firefox 29+, Chrome 10+, Edge 12+, Safari 5.1+, Opera 9.5+

7.4 Row

untested

The Row Component is a container which uses always 100% width and never floats.

egeo-c-row

@mixintestedinternal

Injects the general behavior and properties of the class Row to other components of the UI Kit.

Usage

.test {
     @include egeo-c-row;
}

Will product the next result:

.test {
     box-sizing: border-box;
     display: block;
}

.test:after {
     clear: both;
     content: "";
     display: table;
}

Example

<span class="egeo-c-row">Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Phasellus eget sem sem. Sed eros mi, blandit vel nulla non, sodales mollis libero.</span>
<span class="egeo-c-row">Nam faucibus aliquam mi, sit amet eleifend libero vehicula a. Fusce efficitur posuere lacus, eu tempus dolor volutpat id.</span>

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Phasellus eget sem sem. Sed eros mi, blandit vel nulla non, sodales mollis libero. Nam faucibus aliquam mi, sit amet eleifend libero vehicula a. Fusce efficitur posuere lacus, eu tempus dolor volutpat id.

The egeo-c-row AngularJS directive

Egeo provides an AngularJS directive to create rows with ease. The directive is restricted to HTML Element and called egeo-c-row. The Row component is a container so it allows to use transclude content. Below you can see the properties exposed:

Property Default value Description
content-at-right
false
If the content will be right aligned
variant
none
Background colors. Now b1, b2, b3, b3_dark and b4 are set by default.

Usage

Take a look to the samples shown below to see how the properties could be used and combined to get different results:

<egeo-c-row><egeo-c-button type="submit" modifier="main-1" label="AngularJS Button: Click to test ({{count}})" data-ng-click="count = count + 1"></egeo-c-button></egeo-c-row>
<egeo-c-row data-content-at-right="true"><egeo-c-button type="submit" modifier="main-1" label="AngularJS Button: Click to test ({{count}})" data-ng-click="count = count + 1"></egeo-c-button></egeo-c-row>

Variables exposed to theming

Egeo provides an AngularJS directive to create rows with ease. The directive is restricted to HTML Element and called egeo-c-row. The Row component is a container so it allows to use transclude content. Below you can see the properties exposed:

Property Default value Description
$egeo-c-row---backgrounds
('b1': egeo-get-color(b1), 'b2': egeo-get-color(b2), 'b3': egeo-get-color(b3), 'b3_dark': egeo-get-color(b3_dark),'b4': egeo-get-color(b4))
Background colors. Now b1, b2, b3, b3_dark and b4 are set by default.

Dependencies

  • component
  • clearfix
Compatibility IE8+, Firefox 29+, Chrome 10+, Edge 12+, Safari 5.1+, Opera 9.5+

7.5 Toolbar

untested

The Toolbar Component is a container of items which will be added one behind the other.

egeo-c-toolbar

@mixintestedinternal

Injects the general behavior and properties of the class Toolbar to other components of the UI Kit.

Usage

.test {
     @include egeo-c-toolbar;
}

Will product the next result:

.test {
     box-sizing: border-box;
     display: inline-block;
}

.test__item {
     margin: 0 0 0 8px;
}

.test__item:first-child {
     margin: 0;
}

Example

<span class="egeo-c-toolbar">
     <button>Opt 1</button>
     <button>Opt 2</button>
     <button>Opt 3</button>
</span>

The egeo-c-toolbar AngularJS directive

Egeo provides an AngularJS directive to create toolbars with ease. The directive is restricted to HTML Element and called egeo-c-toolbar. The Toolbar component is a container so it allows to use transclude content. Below you can see the properties exposed:

Property Default value Description
at-right
false
If the content will be right floated

Usage

Take a look to the samples shown below to see how the properties could be used and combined to get different results:

<egeo-c-toolbar>
  <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="main-1" data-label="AngularJS Button: Click to test ({{count}})" data-ng-click="count = count + 1"></egeo-c-button>
  <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="main-2" data-icon-left="icon-cog" data-icon-right="icon-arrow2_down" data-label="AngularJS Button"></egeo-c-button>
  <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="main-3" data-label="AngularJS Button"></egeo-c-button>
  <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-ellipsis" data-rounded="true" data-icon-left="icon-waiting"></egeo-c-button>
</egeo-c-toolbar>

Dependencies

  • component
Compatibility IE8+, Firefox 29+, Chrome 10+, Edge 12+, Safari 5.1+, Opera 9.5+

7.7 App Header

in progressuntested

<egeo-c-app-header data-username="Spongebob Squarepants" data-logo-url="public/assets/images/header.logo.png" data-logo-sref="app.init" data-logo-alt="Stratio Application"></egeo-c-app-header>

7.8 Button Group

untested

The Button Group component is a wrapper to group a set of Egeo Buttons. You can use only the CSS styles but probably has no sense due to the whole functionality is only available via the AngularJS Directive.

The egeo-c-buttongroup AngularJS directive

Egeo provides an AngularJS directive to create button groups with ease. The directive is restricted to HTML Element and called egeo-c-buttongroup. Below you can see the properties exposed:

Property Description
small
Tell to the directive if the more button will be small or not.

Warning: Keep in mind that the egeo-c-buttongroup Angular Directive is only allowed to be used with egeo-c-buttons as inside elements. Use it combined with other elements may have unexpected effects.

Usage

<div data-ng-controller="TestController as TestCtrl">
     <egeo-c-buttongroup>
         <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-1" data-label="Test 1" data-rounded="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime" data-ng-click="TestCtrl.test()"></egeo-c-button>
         <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-1" data-label="Test 2" data-rounded="true" data-small="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime" data-ng-click="TestCtrl.test()"></egeo-c-button>
         <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-2" data-label="Test 3" data-rounded="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime" data-ng-click="TestCtrl.test()"></egeo-c-button>
     </egeo-c-buttongroup>
</div>
<p>The same buttongroup in a container of 110px wide.</p>
<div style="width: 110px" data-ng-controller="TestController as TestCtrl">
     <egeo-c-buttongroup small="true">
         <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-1" data-label="Test 1" data-rounded="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime" data-ng-click="TestCtrl.test()"></egeo-c-button>
         <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-1" data-label="Test 2" data-rounded="true" data-small="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime" data-ng-click="TestCtrl.test()"></egeo-c-button>
         <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-2" data-label="Test 3" data-rounded="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime" data-ng-click="TestCtrl.test()"></egeo-c-button>
     </egeo-c-buttongroup>
</div>
<p>The same buttongroup in a container of 110px wide and right aligned.</p>
<div style="text-align: right; margin-right: 10px;" data-ng-controller="TestController as TestCtrl">
  <div style="display: inline-block; width: 110px" data-ng-controller="TestController as TestCtrl">
     <egeo-c-buttongroup>
         <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-1" data-label="Test 1" data-rounded="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime" data-ng-click="TestCtrl.test()"></egeo-c-button>
         <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-1" data-label="Test 2" data-rounded="true" data-small="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime" data-ng-click="TestCtrl.test()"></egeo-c-button>
         <egeo-c-button data-type="submit" data-modifier="tool-2" data-label="Test 3" data-rounded="true" data-icon-left="icon-datetime" data-ng-click="TestCtrl.test()"></egeo-c-button>
     </egeo-c-buttongroup>
  </div>
</div>

To view the results of click actions, open the Javascript conole of your browser.

The same buttongroup in a container of 110px wide.

The same buttongroup in a container of 110px wide and right aligned.

Dependencies

  • component
  • button
  • popover
Compatibility untested

7.9 Popover

internaluntested

The Popover component, for now, is only available inside other components like the Button Group. For that, in terms of code available to work with, only the CSS has real influence in the code. In short term, this component will be available to be included as a directive in any other component itself.

Dependencies

  • component
Compatibility untested
Created using kss-node and kss-node-template.
